documents.title: Documents
documents.content:
### Visas
Many visitors must obtain a New Zealand Electronic Travel Authority (NZeTA) before arrival. The NZeTA is valid for 2 years and allows multiple entries (up to 3 months per visit; 6 months for UK citizens) [immigration.govt.nz](https://www.immigration.govt.nz/new-zealand-visas/visas/visa/nzeta). You will also pay an International Visitor Levy (IVL). Australian citizens need no visa.

### Departure Taxes
New Zealand includes small border levies in airfares. The NZ IVL is charged on arrival, not departure.

### Customs & Biosecurity
Declare all biosecurity risk items like food, plants, and animal products. A Border Cash Report is required for NZ$10,000+ in cash [customs.govt.nz](https://www.customs.govt.nz/personal/travel-to-and-from-nz/).

culture.title: Culture
culture.content:
### Indigenous Cultures
Māori culture is a prominent part of New Zealand's identity. Formal greetings (like the hongi – pressing noses) are used on marae (meeting grounds) [teara.govt.nz](https://teara.govt.nz/en/nga-tikanga-o-te-marae-marae-protocol). When visiting a marae, you will usually experience a pōwhiri (welcome ceremony).

### Holidays & Festivals
Key public holidays include Waitangi Day (Feb 6), ANZAC Day (April 25), and Matariki (Māori New Year in June/July) [teara.govt.nz](https://teara.govt.nz/en/public-holidays).

### Food Culture
NZ is famous for lamb, fish and chips, pavlova, and Māori hāngi (slow-cooked meat in an earth oven). Café culture is strong, with excellent coffee.

### Environmental Values
New Zealanders hold strong “kaitiakitanga” (guardianship) values. Littering or disrespecting natural sites is socially frowned upon.

safety.title: Safety
safety.content:
### Emergency Numbers
In an emergency dial **111** for police, fire, or ambulance [newzealand.com](https://www.newzealand.com/us/feature/safety-in-new-zealand/). You can also call Healthline at 0800-611-116 for medical advice.

### Wildlife Safety
New Zealand has very little dangerous wildlife. There are no poisonous snakes or spiders. Sandflies can be a nuisance in some areas; use repellent.

### Natural Disasters
- **Earthquakes:** New Zealand is in a seismically active zone. In a tremor: drop, cover, and hold.
- **Volcanoes:** There are active volcanoes, particularly on the North Island. Avoid any restricted zones.
- **Tsunamis:** Though rare, tsunami warnings should be taken seriously. Observe evacuation signage on coasts.

### Legal Considerations
The drinking age is 18. Driving is on the left. Seat belts are mandatory. Do not drink and drive. Recreational drug use is illegal.

health.title: Health
health.content:
### Healthcare System
The Accident Compensation Corporation (ACC) covers accidental injuries for everyone, including visitors. However, illness care is not free, so comprehensive travel health insurance is highly advised [internationalinsurance.com](https://www.internationalinsurance.com/new-zealand/health-insurance/).

### Vaccinations
No specific vaccinations are required for entry. Ensure routine immunizations are up-to-date.

### Sun Safety
New Zealand has high UV radiation. Use sunscreen (SPF 30+), wear a hat, and sunglasses.

### Pharmaceuticals
Bring any special medications in sufficient quantity, in their original packaging with a doctor's prescription.

money.title: Money
money.content:
### Currency & Payment
New Zealand’s currency is the New Zealand dollar (NZD). Credit/debit cards are widely accepted. ATMs are plentiful.

### Costs & Budgeting
Prices are similar to other Western countries. A casual meal may cost ~NZD 15–25. Tap water is safe to drink.

### Tipping
Tipping is not expected, but you can tip around 10% for exceptional service in restaurants.

connectivity.title: Connectivity
connectivity.content:
### Mobile Phones & SIM Cards
The main networks are Spark, One NZ (Vodafone), and 2degrees [esimnewzealand.com](https://esimnewzealand.com/). Tourist SIM plans are available at airports and retail stores. eSIM plans are also available.

### Wi-Fi
Free Wi-Fi is available in many city centers, cafes, and hotels, but having a local SIM is recommended for consistent access.

adaptation.title: Adaptation
adaptation.content:
### Climate Adjustments
New Zealand has a maritime climate with mild summers and cool, wet winters. The weather can change quickly, so pack layers, including a waterproof jacket.

### Lifestyle Tips
Embrace the outdoor lifestyle. New Zealand offers incredible hiking ('tramping'), adventure sports, and stunning natural scenery.

### Social Norms
New Zealanders ('Kiwis') are known for being friendly, laid-back, and informal. Respect for Māori culture is important. Learning a few Māori phrases like “kia ora” (hello) is appreciated.
